overview: Jonah is the story of a reluctant prophet who runs from God's call to preach to Nineveh. It reveals God's compassion for all nations—even Israel's enemies—and exposes human resistance to grace.

verses.text: I knew that you are a gracious God and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love, and relenting from disaster.
And should not I pity Nineveh, that great city, in which there are more than 120,000 persons who do not know their right hand from their left, and also much cattle?

passages.title: Jonah and the Fish
passages.summary: God provides a great fish to swallow Jonah. From its belly, Jonah prays and is delivered—a picture of death and resurrection.

passages.title: Nineveh Repents
passages.summary: Jonah finally preaches to Nineveh, and the entire city—from king to cattle—repents in sackcloth and ashes.

passages.title: Jonah's Anger
passages.summary: Jonah is furious that God spared Nineveh. God gently rebukes his lack of compassion for 120,000 people.

facts.text: Jesus compared His death and resurrection to Jonah's three days in the fish (Matthew 12:40).
Nineveh was the capital of Assyria, Israel's brutal enemy. Jonah didn't want them saved.
The book ends with a question from God—we never learn if Jonah changed his heart.
Jonah is the only prophet who runs away from his call and the only one who sees total success in his preaching.

figures.name: Jonah
figures.description: A prophet who ran from God rather than preach to Israel's enemies. His story reveals both human pettiness and God's vast compassion.

videos.title: Jonah Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores this famous story about God's compassion for all nations.
